Message.Title: Conan O'Brien: "Samsung founder Stefan Jobes"
Message.Msg: - Samsung can hardly explain away all of Apple's smoking guns for intentional copying Wednesday, August 8, 2012 Florian Mueller from FOSSpatents.com In excerpts. "The U.S. trial that started last week has gone fairly well for Apple so far. While jury trials are always somewhat unpredictable, this is an exceptional case in which there appears to be overwhelming evidence in favor of one party: Apple. This impression is further strengthened by indications of unuual nervousness on the part of Samsung's legal team. Samsung's denial of copying now even makes it the laughing stock of TV comedians. Mashable published Conan O'Brien's denial-of-copying video, which features a fake Samsung executive and juxtaposes certain Apple and Samsung products, culminating in a picture of "Samsung founder Stefan Jobes". Considering that this is a serious business issue, a fight over potentially billions of dollars in damages and market share in a market measured in the hundreds of billions of dollars, it's quite unusual for a company's defense to be ridiculed on television. Samsung tries to deny the undeniable. It's all too obvious what Samsung has done. Among the evidence that Apple has put on the table so far, there were two items that I considered particularly impressive: 1. According to Apple's trial brief, Google warned Samsung that its products looked too similar to Apple's and that this would provoke litigation; and 2. In a 2010 internal report, Samsung compared the iPhone to its Galaxy phone and decided that the Galaxy would be more successful if it looked and operated more like the iPhone. Having looked at a certified translation of that Samsung document, I can't help but conclude that similarities between Samsung's subsequently-released smartphones and the iPhone were fully intended. At the more general level of whether Samsung deliberately copied Apple's designs and technologies, Samsung has strategically lost this case in all likelihood. Its claims of being merely an independent innovator and competitor have been reduced to absurdity by the evidence. It would take a reality distortion field of unseen proportions to convince anyone that Samsung created iPhone and iPad lookalikes by mere coincidence. The disaster that Samsung is heading for is an overall decision that will probably be quite consistent with Apple's allegation that Samsung copied Apple's products all the way, from packaging design to physical appearance to user interface elements to operating system architecture. This is not a criminal case, but the outcome may be the next best thing to a "guilty as charged" verdict. That would affect the way Samsung is perceived not only by the market but also by judges who will have to decide on various other infringement claims Apple has brought against Samsung in multiple jurisdictions. If Apple convinces the court that Samsung infringed its rights willfully, I don't think it will take too long before the next California trial over another set of intellectual property rights asserted by Apple. But sooner or later, Apple will have enforced enough intellectual property rights to have major leverage. Samsung made its bed and now has to lie in it. Samsung ignored Google's warnings, and determined that imitation, not independent creation, was the most promising way forward. It has stepped over the line. In the marketplace, that has paid off, but it's probably not going to be tolerated by the court. Apple hasn't won this yet. But a week and a half after the trial started, Apple undoubtedly has the upper hand." http://www.fosspatents.com/2012/08/samsung-can-hardly-explain-away-all-of.html It's looking like Apple might get that Samsung fab plant as settlement, right boys? -

- Oh my! My my my. Samsung used non-admitted attorneys to do their appealing of this and that? Non-admitted to practice law before the United States District Court for the Northern District of California means whatever Samsung's "attorneys" said in Court -- it don't matter. They weren't allowed to be there arguing before the already angry lady Judge. http://www.fosspatents.com/2012/08/samsungs-latest-is sue-with-rules-one.html THIS could be a problem, right boys? Samsung hiring non-admitted badly behaving lawyers. -
- http://www.fosspatents.com/2012/08/samsungs-latest-issue-with-rules-one.html

Message.Msg: for me, so I exited on 8/08 (14.28-14.30) with an average 15% net gain on all holdings accumulated in the most recent ~30 days. Decided to ring the register as I was feeling a little apprehensive (and still do inspite of leaving a few cents on the table today as of this posting). And if I am correct in taking my short term profits, I will definitely re-enter when the dust settles. Disclosure - No Position, but a believer who has made this similiar trade a few times in the past 24+ months and never any regrets.

Safe way to play the earnings in my opinion.

Message.Title: NVIDIA Reports Financial Results for Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2013
Message.Msg: NVIDIA Reports Financial Results for Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2013 Aug 09, 2012 (Marketwire via COMTEX) --NVIDIA (NASDAQ: NVDA) •Revenue of $1.04 billion. •GAAP net income was $119.0 million, or $0.19 per diluted share. Non-GAAP net income was $170.4 million, or $0.27 per diluted share. •GAAP gross margin was 51.8 percent. Non-GAAP gross margin was 52.0 percent. NVIDIA (NASDAQ: NVDA) today reported revenue of $1.04 billion for the second quarter of fiscal 2013 ended July 29, 2012. "Our investments in mobile computing and visual computing are both paying off," said Jen-Hsun Huang, president and chief executive officer of NVIDIA. "Tegra has achieved record sales as tablets come into their own. Our GPU business made strong gains in a weak market, boosted by our breakthrough Kepler architecture. Looking ahead, we're optimistic, as our investments position us right at the center of the fastest growing segments of computing." http://phx.corporate-ir.net/phoenix.zhtml?c=116466&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1724551&highlight=

Topic.Title: Quick Question: I bought covered call strike 15 ex:tomorrow

Message.Msg: If you can tell us what NVDA will be at after your Buy/Sell/Cover/Do nothing - decision, we can tell you what to do. Otherwise the most likely scenario would be 1) Do nothing and get taken and then buy new shares 1st thing in the morning (3 commissions)and stock goes up further (or goes down below $15 at the close and you end up with 6000 shares). 2) Buy back ~ $0.50 - $1 and keep the shares (1 commission) and then the stock tanks or goes further up above ~ $16 3) Do nothing and the stock goes down below $15 at close, and you save some $ not buying the Calls back (~$1 ??) simple math problem :)

Topic.Title: Quick Question: I bought covered call strike 15 ex:tomorrow

Message.Msg: let them take it or hope the whole market crashes. why the hell would you do that? the highest price i saw was $0.57 which locks you into a $15.57 sale. it is a 9% gain if you sold at top but i doubt you did.

Topic.Title: China, Tablets, Tegra, Kepler = INTC BUYOUT @ 25.00!

Message.Msg: A buyout of NVDA is more likely than over techs because of its large cache of cash and minimal debt. A buyer could use the cash to help pay for the buyout. I have seen similar buyouts such as FRPT and Lexar where the buyer used the companies assets to acquire them. I'm not holding my breath about a possible buyout. I'm long NVDA from mid-12s.
I thought that was for the Windows RT tablet, but maybe I heard it wrong.

I will have to go to the summary of the conference call when it comes out, but if I heard right Jen mentioned they had 3 substantial Tegra 3 tablet design wins. He said the Surface, the Nexus 7 and then paused and said there is another win, but he would let the manufacturer announce that win. This has got to be the Amazon Kindle Fire 2 IMHO. I'll double check the CC notes when I get time and confirm this unless someone else caught that in the live recording. Higgins
I thought it was Asus or Asustek.....

Right, but if we're talking about the same part of the call, he was answering a question about Windows RT's launch in tablets and I thought Jen said we had three design wins there and only two had been announced so far. Maybe I mixed it up . . if it's the big three we are talking about, RT or Android, that would be great!
The Nexus was by ASUS, Google had them produce the tablet for them.
It could be the Nexus10
The new oem is Lenovo...

good point! I forgot about the Nexus 10. It could be that tablet. I've heard confirmed reports that the Kindle Fire 2 is supposed to ship with a quad-core chip and be announced in September, which gives the Tegra 3 a good chance to be inside it.
Nvidia Partnering With Lenovo on Windows RT Device - Sources

Topic.Title: WSJL NVIDIA posts strong quarter, guidance on graphics, mobile chips (1)

Message.Msg: (Tegra + Icera + Others) Start with the passing quarter: Q2: $179.70m - Done Q3: $244.39m Q4: $332.37m Q1: $452.02m Q2: $614.75m It will reach $1.6B on next 4 quarters. Tegra's $1B rev target should be met.

MSFT only picks 5 companies for WinRT tablet initial launch. They are MSFT's Surface, Asus, Toshiba, Lenovo & Samsung. If it was refer to 3 out of those 5 companies. IMHO, it should be Lenovo + Asus + Surface.

Message.Title: Should go into the high teens easily at this point
Message.Msg: Considering their growth rate and the postive tone to the entire call, I think the analysts are going to pump this thing up now. The big guys have all taken their positions and now its time to ride it up for the big score. Once the retail investors get in late and at the top to push it even higher, they will start to sell for profit and it will settle down again. The traders are going to make a killing on this stock. They basically said, that their market share is only going to get better and the yields are getting better on 28nm which makes their margins go higher. This being the case, with an increase in revenue and higher margins, their earnings expansion can accelerate quickly. I think in the 15's, you are still looking at a 50% upside potential in 6 to 9 months. What are they going to do with all that cash?
